'Jelszó' means password, however, a passphrase is different to a password in that it's usually longer and is a sequence of words rather than characters.
The two concepts should not be translated with the same word because a passphrase is supposed to add more security than a password, so using the Hungarian equivalent of 'password' for passphrase can be very misleading and prevents a new method of security from being introduced to users that use the translated version.

@dwbit: Well, instances like this present one of the shortcomings of this platform related to how outputs are evaluated and reacted to by other translators.
This output cannot be said to be wrong/incorrect from a linguistic point of view, yet it could still be improved, however, this platform doesn't offer any other option than to flag an output as being incorrect to notify the proofreader (and project managers, etc.) (unless you ping the proofreader directly (@) in the comment).
An option in between the existing ones, for instance, "Recommended translation", should exist as a choice/option in the editor for use in cases like this.
Voting on an already approved output, again, especially in cases like this, doesn't necessarily "get noticed".

@carvalho_leo: Yup, found that out in the meantime. Unfortunately, here in Denmark, the votes are not in (contrary to Sweden) regarding a similar type of titling. A few variants are on the table at the moment, I believe. Thx.

Thanks all, this will appear in a dropdown list for selecting title, if one has not been choosen for your region as of yet, you may leave as is for the time being. I'll check in with the team for more information.
@NCAA Thanks, that is fine, it is there as an option for the time being for those that are familiar with it.
@NCAA I used "neutral" for Finnish too. We don't have an official option either.

@olavinto: Yeah, but you used it first, I adopted it from your translation. :-D
This still isn't ideal, though, but it will have to do until an official policy on this matter is agreed upon and announced. I believe Sweden already uses "Hen".
The problem here in Denmark is that The Danish Language Council, who has the say in linguistic-related matters, have found that alternative titles are not used nearly enough to form a precedent/trend for them to decide then what the official alternative title should be. I just feel that this decision kind of bites its own ass, since it's logical to assume that the reason for the scarce usage of such an alternative is due to the fact that no official one exists.
So an official decision on this matter could indeed have very long perspectives in Denmark.
@NCAA The answer to that would be that things that are simple and straightforward do not equally represent everyone, especially non-binary people :)
@FaviFake: Sure, that would be one perspective...

@kspearrin This button caused confusion in some users, I've noticed. When the app was set to run in the background and this appeared, they assumed that it meant restarting the whole system so they opted to NOT restart. Since there seems to a lot of free space and length shouldn't be an issue, I've changed the Finnish translation to "Restart the app" so that it would be clearer that only the app will be restarted.

trans-unit.note:
@HeartCore The currently approved translation is not correct, please review my translation: "Konto entfernen"
Two things: "Konto entfernen" would be more or less in English "Remove account". But the original English text seems to be "deleteAccount".
As well in English as in German, I think this is not clear and confusing. Do I delete my whole Bitwarden account if I click here? Or do I just "delete" the account from the desktop app? (I didn't test it and am not really completeley sure myself, what of both it is)
If it was "just removing the account from the desktop app, but not really "wipe out" the complete Bitwarden account with all it's data in it", I think maybe in English "remove account" and in German "Konto entfernen" would be less conflicting messages...
If it was "wipe out my complete Bitwarden account with all it's data in it", it can stay "delete Account" and "Konto löschen".
BTW: in the web vault, really deleting the whole Bitwarden account is also called "Konto löschen", and I think in English it would also be "delete account", so this is not ideal for the desktop app, if it means another thing here - and the user get's a panic attack... I myself thought sometimes "hopefully I don't delete my Bitwarden account by accident in the desktop app if I click there by mistake...".

@Entourage9869 for cases like this one, please also tag @kspearrin as he will be able to assist with mistakes in the source string. If this is incorrectly named in the English version as well, it might need to get reported to the devs.

@HeartCore Thanks for the info. I'll try to remeber it. - I'm fairly new to this here - use Bitwarden for a time now, and wanted to "hop in here" because of these few "translation errors", I stumbled upon.

@Entourage9869 sure, no problem. Welcome and thanks for your support!
Kyle is the project manager and thus responsible for such issues.

@HeartCore @kspearrin Ohhh, Sorry, and a bit late... I just clicked "Konto löschen" (should have done that before!) and I now see, it really is "delete the Bitwarden account"... So I deleted my translation and live my life in utter shame from now on.

I think I based this on the current translation in the browser extension - there, "Authenticator key" is currently translated as "Authenticator-Schlüssel". And I think "Authenticator-Schlüssel" would be the better translation here - as it means the TOTP seed code / secret key - and "Authentifizierungsschlüssel" would be even further away from these common terms and a bit misleading also (as the seed code is not even the "Authentifizierungsschlüssel" itself).

trans-unit.source: This action is protected. To continue, please re-enter your master password to verify your identity.

trans-unit.source: Your master password was recently changed by an administrator in your organization. In order to access the vault, you must update it now. Proceeding will log you out of your current session, requiring you to log back in. Active sessions on other devices may continue to remain active for up to one hour.
trans-unit.target: Ditt huvudlösenord ändrades nyligen av en administratör i din organisation. För att få tillgång till valvet måste du uppdatera det nu. Om du fortsätter kommer du att loggas ut från din nuvarande session, vilket kräver att du loggar in igen. Aktiva sessioner på andra enheter kan komma att vara aktiva i upp till en timme.
trans-unit.note: @dwbit: Again, this last part should be amended to "...... Active sessions on other devices may remain active for up to one hour.".
@NCAA makes sense, thanks!
Reminder: "continue to remain". French localization adapted without the redundancy, waiting for the source string to be updated.
@NCAA 👍

trans-unit.source: Your master password does not meet one or more of your organization policies. In order to access the vault, you must update your master password now. Proceeding will log you out of your current session, requiring you to log back in. Active sessions on other devices may continue to remain active for up to one hour.
trans-unit.target: Ditt huvudlösenord följer inte ett eller flera av din organisations regler. För att komma åt ditt valv så måste du ändra ditt huvudlösenord nu. Om du gör det kommer du att loggas du ut ur din nuvarande session så du måste logga in på nytt. Aktiva sessioner på andra enheter kommer fortsatt vara aktiva i upp till en timme.

trans-unit.note: Bitwarden in Croatian uses singular when addressing the user ("tvoj trezor" vs "vaš trezor"), so a plural version here is not the best choice ("Novi ste ovdje"). However there doesn't seem to be a gender neutral version of this question in Croatian ("Nov si ovdje" "Nova si ovdje"). "Vodič za nove korisnike" might be the way to go or simply "Novi korisnik?"

trans-unit.note: @FaviFake why Multifactor Authentication is translated with "Verifica in due passaggi" (two step verification)?

@nicofnt Because a user can't require more than two factors of authentication to log into their Bitwarden account. It's just for consistency, as Bitwarden has almost never used "multifactor authentication" to refer to "2FA".
Given your background in IT, feel free to let me know if there's a difference I'm not aware of between the two terms (in this context).

Hmm. I get your point, normally you would use just two factors (a password and maybe some kind of OTP, Security App, Hardware Token).Anyway, if we can't use "Autenticazione multifattore" I would prefer to use "Autenticazione a due fattori".

@nicofnt Ok nice, thanks for the confirmation.
I'd rather not change it from "verifica in due passaggi", because it's already used everywhere on the 4 Bitwarden Crowdin projects, and also it's just easier for regular people to understand.
For us tech-savvy users, they mean the same thing, but for an average person who isn't familiar with 2fa, "Autenticazione a due fattori" is harder to understand. What's a factor? what does it mean?
"Verifica in due passaggi" is simpler: you type your password, then there's a second "annoying" step, and you're in! Two steps. I suspect this is the reason Google calls it "2SV" instead fo "2FA"
Let me know if I can mark the issues around this as resolved.
@FaviFake OK, you convinced me
@nicofnt 👍

Info for future Filipino translators: "autofill" is used instead of "auto-fill" as the hypens which joins affixes with loanwords (e.g. "i-autofill") will make the translation more cluttered.

context-group.context: A master password is a password that is usually a primary, higher level password. It is the one password to rule them all. In Bitwarden's case it is the main password of a Bitwarden account/vault making it the "master password" for the logins and other data a vault contains.
A secure item container, like a Bitwarden vault.
For example, a tab in a web browser or some other window.
The vault of the currently signed in or active user.
For example, the configuration settings of a browser extension, application or a device.

A Uniform Resource Identifier (URI) is a unique sequence of characters that identifies a logical or physical resource used by web technologies. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Resource_Identifier

Universal 2nd Factor (U2F) is an open standard that strengthens and simplifies two-factor authentication (2FA) using specialized Universal Serial Bus (USB) or near-field communication (NFC) devices based on similar security technology found in smart cards: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Universal_2nd_Factor

A security token is a peripheral device used to gain access to an electronically restricted resource. The token is used in addition to or in place of a password. It acts like an electronic key to access something. Wikipedia: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security_token
Duo Security is a company that provides MFA applications and services. At the time of writing it is a subsidiary of Cisco. https://duo.com

The clipboard is a buffer that some operating systems provide for short-term storage and transfer within and between application programs. The clipboard is usually temporary and unnamed, and its contents reside in the computer's RAM: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clipboard_(computing)

This refers to login information that is required to log in to a service or to unlock something. Can also mean an item containing such information like a Bitwarden login item. Note that "log in" (with a space) is a verb and "login" (without a space) is a noun and while they are related, they mean different things.
An item, like a login, card or a secure note in a Bitwarden vault.
A user account of a web or other service. An account can also refer to another kind of account like a bank account.

In computer science, synchronization refers to one of two distinct but related concepts: synchronization of processes, and synchronization of data. Process synchronization refers to the idea that multiple processes are to join up or handshake at a certain point, in order to reach an agreement or commit to a certain sequence of action. Data synchronization refers to the idea of keeping multiple copies of a dataset in coherence with one another, or to maintain data integrity: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synchronization_(computer_science)
A generator is used generate or create something. In Bitwarden's case a generator is used to generate (or create) passwords and phrases.
A feature or an action for importing something.
An extension or a plugin extends the original features and functionality of something, like for example, a web browser.

Vault timeout determines how your vault will behave after a specified period of inactivity. Timeout is set individually for each Bitwarden app from the Settings. https://bitwarden.com/help/vault-timeout/
A feature or an action for exporting something.

Time-based One-time Password (TOTP) is a computer algorithm that generates a one-time password (OTP) that uses the current time as a source of uniqueness. For Bitwarden Authenticator uses this. Bitwarden

Multi-factor authentication (MFA; encompassing two-factor authentication, or 2FA, along with similar terms) is an electronic authentication method in which a user is granted access to a website or application only after successfully presenting two or more pieces of evidence (or factors) to an authentication mechanism: knowledge (something only the user knows), possession (something only the user has), and inherence (something only the user is). https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-factor_authentication

Web Authentication (WebAuthn) is a web standard published by the World Wide Web Consortium (W3C). WebAuthn is a core component of the FIDO2 Project under the guidance of the FIDO Alliance. The goal of the project is to standardize an interface for authenticating users to web-based applications and services using public-key cryptography. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WebAuthn

Authentication is the act of proving an assertion, such as the identity of a computer system user. In contrast with identification, the act of indicating a person or thing's identity, authentication is the process of verifying that identity. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authentication
A 2FA/MFA authentication application from Google. https://googleauthenticator.net
A 2FA/MFA authentication and password management application from Microsoft. https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/security/mobile-authenticator-app
The name of a company. https://www.microsoft.com

A one-time password (OTP), also known as a one-time PIN, one-time authorization code (OTAC) or dynamic password, is a password that is valid for only one login session or transaction, on a computer system or other digital device. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-time_password
Biometric authentication includes identity verification processes like fingerprint, face and retinal scanning.
Can refer to item specific internal notes or a secure note.
A secure item that can contain text and small file attachements like images and documents.

Self-hosting is a process where an entity like a company or an individual hosts (maintains) a server application of some kind by themselves on their own infrastructure. For example, Bitwarden provides server software for multiple platforms that allow its users to maintain full control over every aspect of their vaults if they do not wish to rely on Bitwarden to do it for them. https://bitwarden.com/help/hosting-faqs/
Bitwarden is an open source password manager (do not translate) https://bitwarden.com/
The profile icon used to represent your Bitwarden account when logged in to the web vault or switching accounts in a Bitwarden client. https://bitwarden.com/help/account-switching/

Folders (in some cases also referred to as directories) are structures used to organize digital files or other items. In Bitwarden you can use them to organize your individual vaults by gathering together logins, cards, identities, and secure notes.
A process of renewing, refreshing or upgrading something, for example reloading a webpage or installing a newer version of an application.
Email can mean a shorter form for an email address and it can also mean terms like an email message, service or mailbox. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Email
Typing/entering/inputting text with a keyboard or by other means.

Can refer to the security code of payment cards (CVV) or some other kind of security/protection code. Context should be known and official locale specific terminology adhered to (the correct translation might change with context).
The action of logging or signing in to something. Note that "log in" (with a space) is a verb and "login" (without a space) is a noun and while they are related, they mean different things.
The action of logging out of something.
Some unique phrase used to uniquely identify something like a user account for example. Like a fingerprint in a text form.

context-group.context: A report is collection of information about something. For example, Bitwarden Vault health reports can be used to evaluate the security of your Bitwarden individual or organization vault and you can send bug reports to a developer. https://bitwarden.com/help/reports/
Policies are rules or sets of rules that define how processes should work, how actions should be performed or who has the right to perform them. https://bitwarden.com/help/policies/

The notification area is the portion of the Windows taskbar that displays icons for system and program features that have no presence on the desktop as well as the time and the volume icon. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Taskbar

In computing, a login session is the period of activity between a user logging in and logging out of a (multi-user) system. It can also mean other time or otherwise limited lifetimes. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Login_session

Collections gather together logins, notes, cards, and identities for secure sharing from an organization. Using collections means adding a set of vault items and individually assigning users to that collection. https://bitwarden.com/help/about-collections/

In computing, depending of context, "domain" is often used to simply describe a web address or a network group. In reality it's more complicated than that and the term is often use in situations where its context might not be very clear. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_domain
hCaptcha is an anti-bot solution that protects user privacy and rewards websites. https://www.hcaptcha.com/

Windows Hello is a security feature in Microsoft Windows that unifies different login methods. These include things like PIN codes, biometrics and security tokens. Should be translated according to Microsoft's official localization. https://support.microsoft.com/windows/learn-about-windows-hello-and-set-it-up-dae28983-8242-bb2a-d3d1-87c9d265a5f0

Touch ID is an electronic fingerprint recognition feature designed and released by Apple Inc. that allows users to unlock devices, make purchases in the various Apple digital media stores (iTunes Store, App Store, and Apple Books Store), and authenticate Apple Pay online or in apps. It can also be used to lock and unlock password-protected notes on iPhone and iPad. Should be translated according to Apple's official localization. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Touch_ID

The official term for the top menu bar in the macOS operating system. This should be translated according to Apple's official localization. Should be translated according to Apple's official localization. https://support.apple.com/guide/mac-help/mchlp1446/mac https://support.apple.com/guide/mac-help/mchlp1446/mac
A privacy oriented search engine. https://duckduckgo.com

Mir is a Russian card payment system for electronic fund transfers established by the Central Bank of Russia under a law adopted on 1 May 2017.The system was developed by Belgian digital payments company OpenWay and is operated by the Russian National Card Payment System, a wholly owned subsidiary of the Central Bank of Russia. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mir_(payment_system)

context-group.context: FIDO ("Fast IDentity Online") supports a full range of authentication technologies, including biometrics such as fingerprint and iris scanners, voice and facial recognition, as well as existing solutions and communications standards. https://fidoalliance.org

Upgrade your individual Bitwarden account to unlock premium password security and management features, including advanced 2FA options, the Bitwarden authenticator (TOTP), encrypted file attachments, emergency access and more. Upgrade now. https://bitwarden.com/help/about-bitwarden-plans/

A security token is a peripheral device used to gain access to an electronically restricted resource. The token is used in addition to or in place of a password. It acts like an electronic key to access something. For example, FIDO U2F -devices are such keys. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Security_token

Start a families organization to share private data between you and five friends or family members. Families organizations include all premium features for all six users and unlimited secure data sharing within the families organization. https://bitwarden.com/help/about-bitwarden-plans/

Start a free organization to store and securely share data with one other user. Free organizations offer both users all the core features of Bitwarden and secure data sharing in up to two collections. Any user of any plan can be the owner of one free organization. https://bitwarden.com/help/about-bitwarden-plans/

A Bitwarden business plan. Start a teams organization to securely share data with your coworkers, department, or entire company. Teams organizations include all premium features for all enrolled users, unlimited secure data sharing within the teams organization, and a suite of operational tools such as event logging and an API for organization management. https://bitwarden.com/help/about-bitwarden-plans/

Enterprise organizations. Start an enterprise organization to secure your business secrets. Enterprise organizations include all premium features for for all enrolled users, all operational tools included in teams organizations, and enterprise-only tools like SSO authentication, enterprise policy enforcement, and a self-host option. https://bitwarden.com/help/about-bitwarden-plans/

Face ID is a facial recognition system designed and developed by Apple Inc. for the iPhone and iPad Pro. The system allows biometric authentication for unlocking a device, making payments, accessing sensitive data, providing detailed facial expression tracking for Animoji, as well as six degrees of freedom (6DOF) head-tracking, eye-tracking, and other features. Should be translated according to Apple's official localization. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Face_ID

context-group.context:
An application programming interface (API) is a way for two or more computer programs to communicate with each other. It is a type of software interface, offering a service to other pieces of software.
https://bitwarden.com/help/bitwarden-apis/

The Bitwarden Public API provides organizations with a suite of tools for managing members, collections, groups, event logs, and policies.
The Public API is a RESTful API with predictable resource-oriented URLs, accepts JSON-encoded request bodies, returns JSON-encoded responses, and uses standard HTTP response codes, authentication, and verbs.
https://bitwarden.com/help/public-api/

The Vault Management API provides Bitwarden users with a suite of tools for managing vault items, including those owned by organizations provided you have the appropriate permissions.
The Vault Management API allows most actions that can be taken by the Bitwarden CLI to be taken in the form of RESTful API calls from an HTTP interface. Using the Vault Management API request that you use the serve command from the CLI to start a local express web server from which to make requests.
https://bitwarden.com/help/vault-management-api/

An application programming interface (API) is a way for two or more computer programs to communicate with each other. It is a type of software interface, offering a service to other pieces of software.
https://bitwarden.com/help/bitwarden-apis/
